The '''Un-word''' or '''Non-word of the year''' ({{lang-de|Unwort des Jahres}}) is an annual publication that names a [[German language|German]] word or word group that is considered to be the year's most offensive new or recently popularized term. ==Description== A German linguists' panel chooses one term that violates human rights or infringes upon Democratic principles, each year. The term may be one that discriminates against societal groups or may be [[Euphemism|euphemistic]], disguising or misleading. The term is usually, but not always a [[German language|German]] term. The term is chosen from suggestions sent in by the public. The choice of the word does not depend on how many times it was suggested/ sent in, but reflects the judgement of the panel. The core of the panel consists of 4 linguists and one journalist. The un-word of the previous year is announced annually in January.{{cite news|title=Wird Pegida das "Unwort des Jahres"?|url=http://www.merkur-online.de/politik/begriff-pegida-vorschlagsliste-unwort-jahres-zr-4595014.html|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=Muenchner Merkur|date=1 January 2015}} ==History== Between 1991 and 1993, the un-word was announced by the ''[[Gesellschaft für deutsche Sprache]]'', alongside the [[Word of the year (Germany)|Word of the Year]]. In 1994, following a row with the then German government led by [[Helmut Kohl]], the jury led by linguist [[Horst Dieter Schlosser]] decided to become independent of any state-funded institution.[http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/ Official website of the linguistic jury responsible for the naming of the un-word of the year (in German)][http://einestages.spiegel.de/external/ShowTopicAlbumBackground/a23795/l0/l0/F.html#featuredEntry [[Spiegel Online]]: ''Ein Jahr, ein (Un-)Wort!'' (in German)] ==List of Un-words of the year since 1991== {| class="wikitable unsortable" |- ! Year || Un-word of the year
(German) || Etymology
English Translation || Explanation |- | 1991 || ''ausländerfrei''{{cite web|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/index.php?id=33|title=Die Unwörter von 1991 bis 1999|publisher=[[Technische Universität Darmstadt]]|language=de}} || free of foreigners || Xenophobic, far-right slogan referring to an (ideal) community without any non-German inhabitants, which came to broad public attention during the [[Hoyerswerda riots]] |- | 1992 || ''ethnische Säuberung'' || [[ethnic cleansing]] || Euphemism popularized during the [[Yugoslav Wars]], referring to the elimination of unwanted ethnic or religious groups by deportation, forcible displacement, and mass murder |- | 1993 || ''[[Überfremdung]]'' || ''lit.'' "over-foreignization", excessive alienation || Xenophobic slogan referring to the fear of the negative impact of migrants on German culture |- | 1994 || ''[[wiktionary:peanuts|Peanuts]]'' || From the English word 'peanuts' || Chosen to criticize the different definitions of an insignificant amount of money by bankers and average people. [[Hilmar Kopper]], then Chairman of the Board of [[Deutsche Bank]], had used the term to refer to a sum of [[Deutsche Mark|DM]] 50 million (roughly 17 million US-$). |- | 1995 || ''Diätenanpassung'' || adjustment of the [[remuneration]] || Euphemism used by members of the [[Bundestag]] to refer to the raising of their monetary rewards. The choice of this un-word criticizes the fact that wages for German MPs are set by the MPs themselves, rather than by an independent body. |- | 1996 || ''Rentnerschwemme'' || ''lit.'' "flood of senior/retired citizens" || Term used in the political discussion about the social difficulties arising from [[population ageing]]. The choice criticizes the "wrong and inhumane impression", the rising number of people in need of a reasonable old-age provision would be "similar to a natural disaster". |- | 1997 || ''Wohlstandsmüll'' || ''lit.'' "prosperity waste" || Deprecatory term coined by [[Helmut Maucher]] (then [[Chief Executive Officer|CEO]] of [[Nestlé]]) during an interview, referring to people who are either presumed unable or reluctant to find employment, who in his opinion would exist because of the highly developed [[welfare]] and [[social support]] systems in Germany. |- | 1998 || ''sozialverträgliches Frühableben'' || ''lit.'' "socially acceptable early passing" || Coined by [[Karsten Vilmar]], then head of the [[German Medical Association]], implying that people who die early into their retirement were considered advantageous for the welfare system. |- | 1999 || ''Kollateralschaden'' || [[collateral damage]] || Military term referring to the incidental destruction of civilian property and non-combatant casualties, which came to broad attention during the [[Kosovo War]] |- | 2000 || ''national befreite Zone''{{cite web|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/index.php?id=34|title=Die Unwörter von 2000 bis 2009|publisher=[[Technische Universität Darmstadt]]|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "nationally liberated zone" || Euphemism used by [[Neo-Nazism|Neo-Nazi]] groups to refer to a region (ranging from a neighborhood to a whole county) defined by a high rate of [[Far-right politics|far-right]] and xenophobic crimes, which are considered [[no-go area]]s by foreigners and leftists. |- | 2001 || ''Gotteskrieger'' || ''lit.'' "God's warriors" || The glorifying synonym for ''[[Mujahideen]]'' was chosen as a reference to the [[Islamism|Islamist]] terrorists responsible for the [[September 11 attacks]] who claimed to act on behalf of a higher power. |- | 2002 || ''Ich-AG''{{cite press release|title=Zum 12. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2002.pdf|date=2003-01-21|language=de}} || ''lit''. "Me, Inc."|| One of the measures of the controversial [[Hartz concept]] (a reform of the German labor market), which allows for unemployed people to be registered as self-employed and thus eligible for public support for a start-up business. The choice of this un-word criticizes the ''Ich-AG'' as a means of artificially lowering the unemployment rate. |- | 2003 || ''Tätervolk''{{cite press release|title=Zum 13. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2003.pdf|date=2004-01-20|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "nation of perpetrators" || The term is used by scholars to refer to a possible [[German collective guilt]] in relation to the initiation of [[World War II]] and the [[Holocaust]]. In 2003, Bundestag member [[Martin Hohmann]] gave a highly controversial speech in which he described an alleged Jewish involvement in the [[Russian Revolution]], using the ''Tätervolk'' term in that context, implying that the term is no more applicable to the Germans than to the Jews. |- | 2004 || ''Humankapital''{{cite press release|title=Unwort des Jahres 2004 gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2004.pdf|date=2005-01-18|language=de}} || [[human capital]] || The choice criticizes that by using this term, individuals were degraded and classified according to economically relevant quantities. |- | 2005 || ''Entlassungsproduktivität''{{cite press release|title=Unwort des Jahres 2005 gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2005.pdf|date=2006-01-24|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "layoff productivity" || Already criticized for being inhumane by then chancellor [[Gerhard Schröder]] in 1998, the usage of this term for a surge of productivity a company may encounter after dismissing employees deemed unnecessary had even found entry into textbooks on economics.{{cite web|title=Unwort des Jahres: "Entlassungsproduktivität"|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/unwort-des-jahres-entlassungsproduktivitaet-a-396973.html|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=24 January 2006}} |- | 2006 || ''freiwillige Ausreise''{{cite press release|title=Zum 16. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2006.pdf|date=2003-01-19|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "voluntary emigration" || A term used in the context of rejected [[Refugee#Asylum seekers|asylum seekers]] who opt for leaving Germany on their own terms rather than being formally deported. The choice of the un-word criticizes the euphemistic nature of that wording, as the emigration would not be "voluntary" after all.{{cite web|title=Unwort des Jahres: "Freiwillige Ausreise"|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/unwort-des-jahres-freiwillige-ausreise-a-460881.html|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=19 January 2007}} (For a similar concept in the United States, see also: [[self-deportation]].) |- | 2007 || ''Herdprämie''{{cite press release|title=Zum 17. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2007.pdf|date=2008-01-15|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "stove bonus" || The term was coined by opponents of the conservative [[Angela Merkel|Merkel]] government's proposal for the introduction of a special allowance for families in which the small children are educated at home instead of sending them to a [[kindergarten]] or similar pre-school institution, alluding to the presumed old-fashioned [[gender role]] of a mother fully dedicated to the raising of her children. Initially used ironically to describe the alleged chauvinistic, retrograde measure, its meaning changed to defame ''any'' parents who keep their children at home, without discussing their actual motives.{{cite web|title=Unwort des Jahres beleidigt viele Eltern|url=https://www.welt.de/kultur/article1555921/Unwort-des-Jahres-beleidigt-viele-Eltern.html|publisher=[[Die Welt]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=15 January 2008}} |- | 2008 || ''notleidende Banken''{{cite press release|title=Zum 18. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2008.pdf|date=2009-01-20|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "suffering/needy banks" || A wording used during the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]], by which banks are characterized as victims, rather than catalysts of the meltdown.{{cite web|title=Sprachkritik: "Notleidende Banken" ist Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/sprachkritik-notleidende-banken-ist-unwort-des-jahres-a-602242.html|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=20 January 2009}} |- | 2009 || ''betriebsratsverseucht''{{cite press release|title=Zum 19. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2009.pdf|date=2010-01-19|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "contaminated by works councils" || This offensive [[neologism]] (reportedly used internally by the ''[[Bauhaus (company)|Bauhaus]]'' management) describes a business with a strong [[works council]], which takes care of the interests of the employees and thus presses for concessions on the employer's side.{{cite web|title=Tiefpunkt in einem Baumarkt|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/sprachmuell-2009-betriebsratsverseucht-ist-unwort-des-jahres-a-672674.html|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=17 May 2010}} |- | 2010 || ''alternativlos''{{cite press release|title=Zum 20. Mal "Unwort des Jahres" gewählt|first=Horst Dieter|last=Schlosser|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2010.pdf|date=2011-01-18|language=de}} || without an alternative || This term was frequently used by German chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] to describe her measures addressing the [[European sovereign-debt crisis]] as the only possible ones. The choice of the un-word criticizes that the term would be undemocratic, as any discussion on the subject would be deemed unnecessary or undesirable.{{cite web|title=Sprachkritik: "Alternativlos" ist das Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/sprachkritik-alternativlos-ist-das-unwort-des-jahres-a-740096.html|publisher=[[Spiegel Online]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=18 January 2011}} {{see also|There is no alternative}} |- | 2011 || ''Döner-Morde''{{cite press release|title=Unwort des Jahres 2011: Döner-Morde|first=Nina|last=Janich|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2011.pdf|date=2012-01-17|language=de}} || [[Bosphorus serial murders|Döner murders]] || A term used by police investigators to describe a series of murders of mostly Turkish shop and restaurant owners between 2000 and 2006, originally attributed to presumed links of the victims to [[organized crime]] groups. In 2011, it was revealed that, in fact, all murders were racial [[hate crimes]] committed by members of a previously unknown terrorist group called ''[[National Socialist Underground]]'', which resulted in widespread criticism of the police for their initial determination.{{cite web|title='Kebab-Murders' called 'worst word of 2011'|url=http://www.thelocal.de/society/20120117-40165.html|publisher=[[The Local]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=17 January 2012}} |- | 2012 || ''Opfer-Abo''{{cite press release|title=Wahl des "22. Unwort des Jahres" |first=Nina|last=Janich|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2012.pdf|date=2013-01-15|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "victim(ization) subscription" || The term was coined by [[Jörg Kachelmann]] in the wake of a trial against him on sexual assault charges, in order to promote his perception that women had the tendency to repeatedly make false claims of crimes such as rape, to further their interests. The choice of the un-word criticizes that this term "unacceptably puts women under general suspicion of inventing sexual violence and of thus being perpetrators themselves."{{cite web|title='Victim subscription' worst phrase of 2012|url=http://www.thelocal.de/society/20130115-47339.html|publisher=[[The Local]]|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=15 January 2013}} |- | 2013 || ''Sozialtourismus''{{cite press release|title=Wahl des 23. "Unwort des Jahres"|first=Nina|last=Janich|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2013.pdf|date=2014-01-14|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "social tourism", welfare tourism || Referring to foreigners in Germany allegedly leeching on the welfare system. |- | 2014 || ''Lügenpresse''{{cite press release|title=Wahl des 24. "Unworts des Jahres"|first=Nina|last=Janich|publisher=Sprachkritische Aktion Unwort des Jahres|url=http://www.unwortdesjahres.net/fileadmin/unwort/download/2014.pdf|date=2015-01-13|language=de}} || ''lit.'' "liar press",{{cite news|author1=Erik Kirschbaum|title=Revived Nazi-era term 'Luegenpresse' is German non-word of year|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/13/us-germany-islam-protests-idUSKBN0KM21F20150113|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=Reuters|publisher=Thompson Reuters|date=13 January 2015}} [[lying press]]{{cite news|author1=Kate Connolly|title=Pegida: what does the German far-right movement actually stand for?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/shortcuts/2015/jan/06/pegida-what-does-german-far-right-movement-actually-stand-for|accessdate=16 January 2015|work=The Guardian|date=6 January 2015}} || A term that was initially used in the [[First World War]] before being revived by the [[Nazis]] in the lead-up to the [[Second World War]], and which has since been revived by the [[Pegida]] movement to describe media outlets that they believe to have been infiltrated by left-wing influences and therefore to be spreading lies about the political establishment, immigration, asylum and the Pegida movement itself. |- |2015 |''[[Gutmensch]]''{{Cite news|title = Sprachkritik: "Gutmensch" ist Unwort des Jahres 2015|url = http://www.sueddeutsche.de/kultur/-gutmensch-ist-unwort-des-jahres-1.2814403|newspaper = sueddeutsche.de|access-date = 2016-01-12|issn = 0174-4917|language = de}} |"do-gooder"/"upstanding citizen" |Used pejoratively, predominantly by followers of movements like [[Pegida]] {{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}, to mock those who "do good" by supporting diversity{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}, multiculturalism{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} and refugees in Germany{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}; used to criticize what they believe to be liberals' blindness to the threats posed by foreigners in Germany{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}}. |- | 2016 || ''Volksverräter''{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/unwort-des-jahres-2016-volksverraeter-a-1129297.html |language=German |work=Der Spiegel |date=10 January 2017 |title="Volksverräter" ist das Unwort des Jahres 2016}} || "Traitor of the people"{{cite news |title='Traitor of the people' is Germany's worst word of 2016: Here's why |work=The Local |date=10 January 2017 |url=https://www.thelocal.de/20170110/traitor-of-the-people-is-germanys-worst-word-of-2016-heres-why }} || A Nazi-era term revived by anti-immigration right-wing groups including [[Alternative for Germany|AfD]]{{Citation needed|date=October 2018}} and [[Pegida]]. |- |2017 |''Alternative Fakten''{{Cite news|url = http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/unwort-des-jahres-2017-jury-waehlt-alternative-fakten-a-1188101.html |work=Der Spiegel |access-date = 2018-01-16|language = de| title = Sprachkritik: "Alternative Fakten" ist Unwort des Jahres 2017}} |"[[alternative facts]]" |Obscuring and misleading expression for the attempt to establish false claims as legitimate means of public discourse.Translated from {{Cite news|title = Das "Unwort des Jahres" 2017 heißt "alternative Fakten"|url = http://www.sueddeutsche.de/news/leben/gesellschaft-das-unwort-des-jahres-2017-heisst-alternative-fakten-dpa.urn-newsml-dpa-com-20090101-180116-99-653662|newspaper = sueddeutsche.de|access-date = 2018-01-16|language = de}} |} ==See also== *[[Word of the year]] *[[Word of the year (Germany)]] ==References== {{reflist|20em}} [[Category:Word of the year]] [[Category:German language]] [[Category:1992 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Ironic and humorous awards]]

{{Infobox person | name = Victor Hochhauser | honorific_suffix = {{postnominals|country=GBR|CBE}} | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1923|03}} | birth_place = [[Košice]], [[Czechoslovakia]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = British | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = [[Hampstead]], London, England | education = | alma mater = | occupation = music promoter | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = Lilian Hochhauser ({{nee}} Shields) | parents = | children = 4 | relations = | website = }}
'''Victor Hochhauser''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|CBE}} (born March 1923) is a British music promoter. He and his wife Lilian have been called "Britain's foremost independent promoters of classical music and ballet".<ref name="telegraph.co.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/theatre/dance/10988191/Victor-and-Lilian-Hochhauser-exclusive-interview.html|title=Victor and Lilian Hochhauser: exclusive interview|publisher=}}</ref>
Hochhauser was born in March 1923<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/officers/Vc0cJFuyw9Boza1pjT7zTHtn-QM/appointments|title=Victor HOCHHAUSER - Personal Appointments (free information from Companies House)|publisher=}}</ref> in [[Košice]], [[Czechoslovakia]], the son of an industrialist father. His grandfather and great-grandfather were rabbis.<ref name="telegraph.co.uk"/>
His career as an impresario started in 1945 at London's [[Albert Hall]].<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2010/jul/17/victor-hochhauser-impresario|title=Victor Hochhauser: 'My great stroke of luck came when Stalin died'|first=Nicholas|last=Wroe|date=16 July 2010|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
Hochhauser was appointed Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] in 1993.<ref name="thejc.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.thejc.com/culture/interviews/interview-lilian-and-victor-hochhauser-1.12739|title=Lilian and Victor Hochhauser - The Jewish Chronicle|first=Jessica|last=Duchen|date=3 December 2009}}</ref>
He met his future wife Lilian Shields, born in Britain to Russian-Jewish parents, when they were both working for Rabbi Dr [[Solomon Schonfeld]] in London.<ref name="thejc.com"/> They married in 1949 and had four children together.<ref name="auto"/>

{{Infobox video game |image=ytagbox.jpg |image_size=250px |caption=North American box art |developer=[[Nintendo EAD|Nintendo EAD Group No. 4]] |publisher=[[Nintendo]] |director=[[Hiroyuki Kimura]] |producer=[[Takashi Tezuka]] |composer=[[Toru Minegishi]]

''Commercial availability''{{vgrelease|NA|April 9, 2015|PAL|July 23, 2015}}''Free download promotion''{{cite web|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2015/06/nintendo_download_25th_june_europe|title=Nintendo Download: 25th June (Europe)|last=Whitehead|first=Thomas|quote=Download Yoshi's Woolly World on the eShop and receive a free code for Yoshi Touch & Go - deal available until 23rd July, code valid until 20th August.|publisher=Nintendo Life|date=June 22, 2015|access-date=July 23, 2015}}{{vgrelease|AUS|June 25, 2015|EU|June 26, 2015}} |genre=[[Platform game|Platforming]] |modes=[[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Yoshi Touch & Go''''', known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''Catch! Touch! Yoshi!'''|キャッチ!タッチ!ヨッシー!|Kyatchi! Tatchi! Yosshī!}}, is a [[video game]] that was developed and published by [[Nintendo]] for the [[Nintendo DS]]. It debuted in Japan on January 27, 2005, in North America on March 14, 2005,{{cite web | url=http://ds.ign.com/objects/682/682834.html | title=Yoshi Touch & Go | publisher=[[IGN]] | accessdate=2006-02-02}} and in Europe on May 6, 2005. As of August 2007, the game sold 197,337 copies in Japan.{{cite web|url=http://www.kotaku.com/gaming/famitsu/kotaku-magu-famitsu-lists-100-biggest-sellers-on-ds-in-japan-221734.php |title=100 Biggest Sellers On DS In Japan |publisher=kotakumagu.com |date=2006-12-14 |accessdate=2006-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070125015321/http://www.kotaku.com/gaming/famitsu/kotaku-magu-famitsu-lists-100-biggest-sellers-on-ds-in-japan-221734.php |archivedate=January 25, 2007 }} ''Yoshi Touch & Go'' was produced by [[Takashi Tezuka]] and directed by [[Hiroyuki Kimura]]. It was one of the launch titles for the DS in Japan. The game was released on the [[Wii U]] [[Virtual Console]] in 2015. The game revolves around [[Yoshi]] and [[Baby Mario]]/[[Baby Luigi]]. Its graphical style and cast of characters originate from ''[[Yoshi's Island|Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island]]''. The game heavily utilizes the DS's touch screen capabilities, and makes use of the microphone as well. The challenge in the game comes from replaying the same modes over and over to get the best possible score, similar to the classic [[arcade game]]s of the 1980s. Therefore, the difficulty of the game is based primarily on improving one's own skill. ==Gameplay== The game begins with three different gameplay modes: "Score Attack", "Marathon", and the "multiplayer vs. mode". Additionally, the player can unlock "Time Attack" and "Challenge modes" by getting the [[high score]] in the "Score Attack" and "Marathon" modes. When the high score on the two new modes is achieved, the mini-game "Balloon Trip" is unlocked. There are two basic level types: a vertical level, where the player must lead Baby Mario through the sky safely to the ground; and a [[side-scrolling]] level, where the player takes control over different colored Yoshis, carrying Baby Mario on their back. As opposed to the earlier ''Yoshi'' games, in ''Yoshi Touch & Go'' the player cannot take direct control over the characters. Instead, the Yoshis move from the left to the right automatically at a certain speed. However, the player can draw lines on the lower screen with the stylus, which creates clouds that will support a character. This attribute allows to create alternate routes to avoid enemies and obstacles. If the drawn clouds are impeding progress, they disappear by blowing into the microphone. Enemies can be dispatched by drawing circles on them, which puts most of them into a bubble. In the side-scrolling level, a Yoshi can make an egg out of fruits by leading them to its mouth. By tapping on the screen, the Yoshi will launch an egg in that direction, which is useful for killing enemies or collecting coins and fruits. By tapping on a Yoshi himself, the player can make him jump, and tapping him again while he's in midair will cause him to do a flutter-kick jump. The [[Nintendo DS]]'s two screens act as one tall screen, whereas the player can only create clouds on the lower one. However, by throwing eggs in the upper screen it is possible to collect coins or fruits from there. An exception provides the wireless "multiplayer vs. mode", where only the lower screen shows the player's view, while the upper screen shows that of the enemy. In the multiplayer, the goal is to be faster than the enemy. By clearing out enemies on the own screen, the player can cause spiky obstacles on the opponent's screen. In some modes, there is a star point counter. Once this reaches 100, a [[Starman (Nintendo)|Super Star]] will appear. If Yoshi touches it or the player drags it to Yoshi, Baby Mario will temporarily become Super Baby [[Mario]], who is considerably faster than Yoshi and has unlimited stars (instead of eggs) to throw. The star points will then return to zero. Also, by feeding fruits to Yoshi a certain number of eggs will be replenished. The number of replenished eggs consists of the fruit (for instance, an apple only refills one egg, while melons refill twenty). The color of Yoshi that Baby Mario rides depends on the player's score in the vertical falling part of the game. If the player gets 60 points, he will ride a light blue Yoshi, and then the color will go up a level for every other 20 points scored (for instance, pink Yoshi at 80 points, blue Yoshi at 100 points, etc.). The only two exceptions are white and orange Yoshi: In Marathon mode, when Baby Mario changes Yoshis, depending on the player's performance he might start riding a white Yoshi, who will switch to black Yoshi, unless it's at the 10,000 meters mark, in which case he will switch over to orange Yoshi. It will then switch to purple Yoshi at 20,000 meters in Marathon. In challenge mode, after the high score is beaten, getting 0 points in the Baby Mario segment of future games will unlock a fast purple Yoshi. The same applies to time attack where a white Yoshi, which has unlimited eggs, can be unlocked. ==Development== According to director [[Hiroyuki Kimura]] and designer Keizo Ohta, ''Yoshi Touch & Go'' was originally planned to be designed for the [[Nintendo GameCube]] as "Balloon Trip".{{cite web | url=http://www.n-sider.com/articleview.php?articleid=425 | title=The Making of Yoshi Touch & Go | publisher=N-Sider | date=April 10, 2005 | accessdate=2006-01-30}} A demo of the game was first exhibited during the [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]] of 2004 and gained positive response. Thereupon, the executives of Nintendo green lighted the project. [[Shigeru Miyamoto]] considered that the game would create a bigger impact as a DS title. ''Yoshi Touch & Go'' was produced by [[Takashi Tezuka]] and director by Hiroyuki Kimura. The game's musical score was created by [[Toru Minegishi]], Asuka Ohta, and [[Kazumi Totaka]]. Baby Mario and Baby Luigi were voiced by [[Charles Martinet]] while the voice-over of the Yoshis was done by Totaka,{{cite web | url=http://www.n-sider.com/gameview.php?gameid=881&view=credits | title=Yoshi Touch & Go Credits | publisher=N-Sider | accessdate=2006-01-30}} including the 19-note song he did. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = 75.01%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ds/924890-yoshi-touch-and-go/index.html |title=Yoshi Toush & Go |website=[[GameRankings]] |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=September 3, 2013}} | MC = 73/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ds/yoshi-touch-go/critic-reviews |title=Yoshi Touch & Go Critic Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=CBS Interactive |accessdate=September 3, 2013}} | GSpot=7.2/10{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/yoshi-touch-and-go/reviews/yoshis-touch-and-go-review-6120330/ |title=Yoshi's Touch & Go Review |author=Davis, Ryan |date=March 11, 2005 |website=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=September 3, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530185018/http://www.gamespot.com/yoshi-touch-and-go/reviews/yoshis-touch-and-go-review-6120330/ |archivedate=May 30, 2013 }} | IGN = 8.8/10{{cite web | url=http://ds.ign.com/articles/595/595523p1.html | title=Yoshi Touch & Go Review | last=Harris | first=Craig | date=March 11, 2005 | publisher=[[IGN]] | accessdate=September 3, 2013}} | rev1 = ''[[USA Today]]'' | rev1Score = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web| last=Gudmundsen | first=Jinny | title=Yoshi Touch & Go Review | url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/columnist/jinnygudmundsen/2005-03-29-jinny_x.htm | publisher=[[USA Today]] | date=March 29, 2005 | accessdate=September 3, 2013}} }} The game was generally well received, though not as positively as earlier games of the ''Yoshi'' series, such as ''[[Yoshi's Island]]''. It holds average ratings of 75% at [[GameRankings]] and 73/100 at [[Metacritic]]. Craig Harris of IGN said it "is one of the most original and unique games created for the system so far, and it's truly a design that's unlike anything you've played before." He especially commended the multiplayer mode and gave the game an 8.8/10. Additionally, it won the IGN Editors' Choice Award on March 11, 2005.{{cite web| title=IGN Editors' Choice Games | url=http://ds.ign.com/index/choice.html | publisher=[[IGN]] | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080716202100/http://ds.ign.com/index/choice.html |archivedate=July 16, 2008 |deadurl=yes}} Some reviewers, however, criticised ''Yoshi Touch & Go'' for its lack of storyline and the simple gameplay.{{cite web| last=Jacobs | first=Ben | title=Yoshi Touch & Go Review | url=http://www.etoychest.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=833&Itemid=42 | publisher=eToychest | accessdate=2006-02-02}} GameSpot's Ryan Davis found that he was "going through the same few levels over and over again" and thought the multiplayer mode was not very compelling, concluding that although "the gameplay concepts(...)are quite good," the overall package "simply lacks substance." Also, the game gathered negative criticism for its price, which was found too high by some critics.{{cite web| title=Yoshi Touch & Go Reader Reviews | url=http://rr.ds.ign.com/rrobj/ds/object/682834/ | publisher=[[IGN]] | accessdate=2006-02-02}} Nevertheless, ''Touch & Go'' was a moderate success, selling 197,337 copies in Japan. {{Wikipedia books|Mario franchise video games|Mario video games}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.nintendo.co.jp/ds/ayij/}} {{jp icon}} *[http://www.gamespot.com/ds/action/yoshi/index.html ''Yoshi Touch & Go''] at [[GameSpot]] {{Yoshi series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yoshi Touch and Go}} [[Category:2005 video games]] [[Category:Cancelled GameCube games]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment Analysis and Development games]] [[Category:Yoshi games]] [[Category:Video game prequels]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games scored by Kazumi Totaka]] [[Category:Virtual Console games]] [[Category:Virtual Console games for Wii U]]
